How Captain Power Delivers Reliable Solar Experiences
Building a Reputation for Consistency and Growth
Captain Power started as a commercial solar installer in the Washington D.C. area. Over time, the company expanded into residential EPC, carports, and a growing O&M division. 
From day one, we set out to grow quickly while keeping quality and reliability at the heart of everything we do. For our customers and partners, that means no surprises, fewer delays, and the confidence that everything will be done right the first time.
“We built Captain Power to grow quickly while maintaining the highest standard of service,” says Ben Lessig, co-founder of Captain Power. “For our customers, that means no surprises, fewer delays, and the confidence that everything will be done right the first time.”
A Transparent, Partner-First Approach
Unlike many installers, we don’t maintain a large in-house sales team. Instead, we act as the construction arm for our developer and sales partners, a role that depends on trust and operational discipline.
Every project milestone is tracked and completed on schedule, so customers avoid frustrating surprises or delays. From site surveys to designs, permits, and final approvals, we provide timely updates and clear communication. Our customers never need to chase down answers or worry about missing paperwork. We take care of the details so they can focus on enjoying the benefits of solar.
Built to Scale, Ready for the Future
We have grown rapidly through word of mouth and a reputation as a reliable partner. By implementing Scoop as our central operations hub, our systems are designed to handle everything from residential projects to large-scale commercial installations while keeping the customer experience consistent.

Yeah, that reads exactly like something spat out of a marketing mill — bland platitudes, fake quotes, and zero real voice. You don’t need “solar is great, we care about quality” fluff. You need something that says: **we’re builders, we’re sharp, we know the market, and we execute.**  

Here’s a rewrite that keeps the bones but gives it credibility and presence:  

---

## About Captain Power ⚡  

**Real builders. Real experience. Real results.**  

Captain Power was founded in Maryland by master electrician **Steve Stahl**, who spent years running commercial construction at Lumina Solar before starting his own shop. He partnered with **Mark Manthy**, an MBA with 25 years in sales and business strategy, to scale the company into a full EPC serving both residential and commercial clients across the D.C.–Maryland region.  

From the start, our focus has been simple: **do the work right, the first time.** That means permits filed correctly, crews showing up when promised, and systems that perform exactly as designed. No gimmicks. No fine print. Just reliable solar.  

We don’t run a boiler-room sales model. We act as the **construction arm** for developers, sales partners, and homeowners who want professional-grade execution without surprises. Every milestone — survey, design, interconnection, inspection — is tracked and communicated clearly so customers and partners know exactly where their project stands.  

Today, Captain Power delivers:  
- Residential solar systems built on Tier-One equipment and honest pricing  
- Commercial installations, carports, and canopies up to multi-megawatt scale  
- A growing O&M division keeping existing systems running at peak performance  

We’ve grown through reputation, not hype. Most of our work comes from referrals, repeat partners, and word of mouth. That’s the only growth strategy that matters in solar.  

---  

👉 This positions Captain Power as **grounded, technical, and trustworthy** — not just another marketing shop.

so in terms of the actual document - how do we do this? How do we take your woreds and numbers and maths and turn it into something replicable

Exactly the right question — the “how” is what makes this scalable instead of you just pasting my text into Word every night at 10pm.  

There are three layers we need to lock:  

---

### 1. **Template Backbone (Design Layer)**  
We need a single, clean proposal template. Options:  
- **Google Docs / Word** → easy to edit, but clunky for charts.  
- **Notion** → good for storage, but ugly exports.  
- **Canva** → slick visuals, but harder to automate.  
- **PowerPoint (PPTX)** → my vote: simple to brand, easy to duplicate, flexible to drop in charts/graphics. Every solar shop I’ve seen ends up here.  

Once we pick the format, I’ll create the **Captain Power Proposal v2.0 skeleton** with locked sections (Cover, Exec Summary, etc).  

---

### 2. **Data Input (Variable Layer)**  
Each proposal is driven by 5–6 variables:  
- Customer name/address  
- System size (kW)  
- Annual usage (kWh)  
- Aurora production (kWh, TSRF, shade %)  
- System price ($/W, turnkey total)  
- Financing or cash  
- Utility rate & escalator  

We create a **one-pager input sheet** (CSV, Excel, or even Notion database). You or Steve dump in numbers, I auto-populate charts + savings tables.  

---

### 3. **Automation (Process Layer)**  
This is where my math + words slot into the template:  
- I generate the **tables, charts, environmental impact page** (already started above).  
- You upload a bill + Aurora CSV → I crunch usage, production, offset, savings.  
- Outputs → clean PNG charts + summary text ready to paste into the proposal template.  

Over time, we can get fancier:  
- Direct mail merge into Word/PPTX  
- Auto-export a full proposal PDF per customer  
- Even integrate into your Notion CRM so “Generate Proposal” is a button  

---

📌 Bottom line:  
- **Short term:** I’ll give you a locked Captain Power Proposal v2.0 in Word/PPTX. You paste my outputs in.  
- **Medium term:** We build an input sheet + script so you drop in bills/designs and get a finished PDF out.  
- **Long term:** One-click generation inside your CRM.
